intro: Selinum carvifolia-chabraei, commonly known as the narrow-leaved selenium, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in umbels, a typical feature of the family. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine or arid environments. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal potential, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and traditional herbal practices.
